body: One of the biggest reasons for me making the switch was that it was indeed a small composer change, but also to be able to have both old and new style to keep working alongside each other. Therefore being able to compare while running two PHP web servers simultaneously during development.

I would like to provide 3 default calendars:
1. Home - `VEVENT` only.
2. Work - `VEVENT` only`.
3. Tasks - `VTODO` only.

Instead of the name `default` though, they should be based on a UUID. (Use Sabre\DAV\UUIDUtil to generate one).

Why did you keep this comment?
oh, that was when i was doing tests, deleted it on e8320ff738823ba87fb559a2c323e53a1727a34e
would it make sense to check whether the ini-values is already higher then 3600 and don't ini_set 3600 then?

One thing I found out using this URL structure, was using email addresses as usernames might break.
We should think about whether we want to take this path.

Have you thought about using `utf8mb4` as character set?

`$pdo->exec("SET CHARACTER SET utf8mb4");`
I think @ should be fine, as long as its urlencoded. Some DAV clients don't love it though, but i suppose that's unrelated

I personally like to assert valid state when constructing an object, instead of having to know to call this method when persisting or at least having a point of (or forgetting to do) validation. Thoughts?
Why do you change these to public? do you have a use case for using properties directly?

@dennisdegreef , well, utf8mb4 is something that needs to be set during table creation. Which we do. I think in case of mysql the current recommendation is to actually add `charset=utf8` to the mysql DSN, or run `SET NAMES 'UTF-8'`.

The issue I have is that what's valid for creation, is not necessarily valid for updating. This is also why I added two different functions. A solution to that is to make more of a CQRS-style system where we're not modelling a User, but rather a UserCreationOperation and UserUpdateOperation, but I'm also a bit worried there about creating too much complexity.

I agree that the 'opt-in' can be a bit dangerous, and it's also not amazing that a Domain object can have a valid or invalid state, but I thought this approach would make it the simplest for a intermediate dev to fully grasp where what is being done... 

I'm open to suggestions though. This is simply what I came up with looking at your existing source, and having to make it work predictably and correctly with the UserRepository (which was incomplete before).

Less typing I suppose ;) This comment ties into your other comment though. If the object is allowed to have an invalid/incomplete state, making the properties public is not a big deal, because we're doing validation a bit later anyway.

For what it's worth, I carry the very unpopular opinion (within the current PHP metagame) that less code is better and actually results in more maintainability, instead of all the layers of complexity people keep on coming up with. 1 class per field is a big no-no for me. I can live with a bit of duplication if it means that more related code sits together in the same class. I'll add an interface or class when I need it, not if I anticipate needing it later.... if you catch my drift.

I hope that's not too frustrating, I do fully realize that I'm going against common sensibilities.
